comment_text:
Note: The US Navy put no restrictions on me about what I should say or how I should present what I learned on this trip. Other than making sure my footage was cleared for Operational Security, I am free to say whatever I want about this experience. And here is what I want to say:

This was an absolutely incredible experience. The Navy personnel and Academic Research Scientists who kept me safe were incredibly professional. Every person I met was exceptional. Also, can I just say that the experience of going underway in a submarine was INCREDIBLE. I'm still trying to decide how I want to release the footage (when I receive the last of it after it's been OPSEC cleared). Right now I'm leaning towards a series of videos similar to a Smarter Every Day Deep Dive on the submarines. The name is certainly fitting!

I've also given a lot of thought to recent events here at home and around the world. It occurs to me that the US Navy brings stability and security to the world in a very unique way these days. I'm grateful that I had the opportunity to meet these individuals so I now know how professional these people are.

I also want to say thank you to people who support Smarter Every Day on Patreon. My goal is to make intelligent, humble, respectful content. I was given approval for this experience provided I could purchase all the necessary cold weather gear and find a way to get there. Patrons of Smarter Every Day made that happen, so thank you to everyone who partners with me to make this kind of content by supporting at https://www.patreon.com/smartereveryday. If you're new here, please consider a sub! (lol)

Warm Regards,
Destin

-20°C isn't so bad. Below -15°C you'll start to feel your nose hairs freeze a little. It's a very funny tugging feeling, and it just gets more and more intense the colder it becomes. I mean, it's not like it's annoying, but it's noticeable. Once you pass -30°C, it starts to get cold tho. And at -40°C it starts to get dangerous if you stay out for too long or don't know what you're doing. Granted anything below +5°C can be dangerous if you get wet, or if it gets windy. And in fact cold but above 0 temps are more dangerous than the really cold ones, due to how you don't notice that you're going into hypothermia. At least at below -15°C you'll notice your limbs starting to burn.

My grandpa used to do what you do, he used to be a photographer in weapons testing and development as well as a liaison between lockheed-martin and the US gov't testing and developing those aircraft during vietnam and the cold war. He worked in alaska testing weapon and aircraft function in extreme cold weather and would go to Yuma to do those same tests in extremes on the opposite side of the environmental spectrum. Seeing the landscape and hearing you talk about the cold--he told us about how some days in the winter it was so cold, they had to hook up massive heaters to the helicopter engines in the hangar, and they had about a full minute to get the helicopter out of the hangar and get the turbine started and after about a minute if you couldn't get it started it was too cold to run. The turbine would slow down and eventually wouldn't want to turn anymore and they'd have to roll the heli back into the hangar and on a heater to heat for another 30-45 minutes again before they could make another attempt to turn it again. It's insane to think about the temperature physics at play with that. It can be so cold outside that the cold can suck 45 minutes of heat out of a massive turbine in such a short period of time.

15:23 In other words :
The submarine knows where it is at all times. It knows this because it knows where it isn't. By subtracting where it is from where it isn't, or where it isn't from where it is (whichever is greater), it obtains a difference, or deviation. The navigation subsystem uses deviations to generate corrective commands to drive the submarine from a position where it is to a position where it isn't, and arriving at a position where it wasn't, it now is. Consequently, the position where it is, is now the position that it wasn't, and it follows that the position that it was, is now the position that it isn't.
In the event that the position that it is in is not the position that it wasn't, the system has acquired a variation, the variation being the difference between where the submarine is, and where it wasn't. If variation is considered to be a significant factor, it too may be corrected by the acoustic navigation and communication system. However, the submarine must also know where it was.
The submarine navigation computer scenario works as follows. Because a variation has modified some of the information the submarine has obtained, it is not sure just where it is. However, it is sure where it isn't, within reason, and it knows where it was. It now subtracts where it should be from where it wasn't, or vice-versa, and by differentiating this from the algebraic sum of where it shouldn't be, and where it was, it is able to obtain the deviation and its variation, which is called error.

It's so odd seeing Fairbanks in a video. Also, when you were crossing the road, they were laughing at you because you were wearing a parka. You don't wear parkas unless it's super super cold and windy, other than that, you don't wear parkas ever. We just wear a heavy jacket, hat that covers the ears a bit, and gloves. There's times when you do wear more than that, but unless it's required, jeans, jacket, hat, boots, and gloves are it. We don't wear a jacket until it starts getting lower than 20°F and that's just a light jacket, nothing else unless it's lower or windy. Usually we don't even wear the gloves and hat, just go without, doesn't bother us.
I'm living in Oklahoma now, which is awful with the heat, but I'd go back to the cold in a heartbeat even though I only lived there 6 years. Living everywhere is a bit odd but you get to decide where you want to end up. Growing up Army is awesome and living in Fairbanks is even better.

Hey Destin. The phenomenon with the sun is called a sun dog and it occurs from the ice crystals that are in the air. Basically, fine powdery snow in real cold places is picked up by the wind and eventually can create a light “mist” of ice.  This refracts the light of the sun. When seen when the sun is really close to the horizon, it makes it appear like there are actually three suns!!

When they spoke about the salt water, it was interesting because the saltier it is, the less the ice has been melting and diluting it with fresh water. They have a test called a "specific gravity test" which is a simple method to determine the same thing, salt water is denser than fresh and makes a little floating measuring device more buoyant in it and that tells them how much ice has been melting.  Multi year ice is Blue.
That weird sun halo you saw is called a sun dog! Very common in higher latitudes for the exact reason you said - the ice crystals that are suspended in the atmosphere!

The rainbow halo is called a circumhorizontal arc, the same thing that creates "fire rainbows" or rainbow clouds, or just random fragments of rainbow in the sky. Just naturally, the arctic has a lot of ice crystals in the atmosphere giving more opportunities to create lots of little prisms. Upon what were its foundations sunk? Or who laid its corner-stone, when the morning stars sang together, and all the sons of Elohim shouted for joy? Or who enclosed the sea with doors, when it burst forth and came from the womb; when I made the clouds its garment, and thick darkness its swaddling band; and assigned for it My law, and set bars and doors; and said, ‘This far you have come, but no farther, and here your proud waves stop?’ Have you ever commanded the morning, and caused the dawn to know its place, to take hold of the ends of the earth, and the wrong be shaken out of it? It is changed like clay under a seal, and they stand out like a garment. And their light is withheld from the wrong, and the arm lifted up is broken. Have you come to the sources of the sea? Or have you walked about in the recesses of the deep? Were the gates of death revealed to you? Or have you seen the gates of the shadow of death? Have you understood the breadth of the earth? Declare, if you know it all. Where is the way to the dwelling of light? And darkness, where is its place, that you should take it to its boundary, and know the paths to its home? Do you know? For you would have been born then, and the number of your days been many! Have you entered into the storehouses of snow, or have you seen the storehouses of hail, which I have kept for the time of distress, for the day of fighting and battle? Where is the way that light is divided, or the east wind scattered over the earth? Who has cleft a channel for the overflowing water, or a way for the thunderclaps to make rain fall on land where no one is, a wilderness in which there is no man; to satisfy the wild and waste places, and to make the seeds of grass to sprout? Does the rain have a father? Or who has brought forth the drops of dew? From whose belly comes the ice? And who gave birth to the frost of the heavens? The waters harden like stone, and the surface of the deep is frozen. Do you bind the bands of Kimah, or loosen the cords of Kesil? Do you bring out the Mazzaroth/ constellations in its season? Or do you lead the Bear with its sons? Do you know the Torah/ laws of the Shamayim/ heavens? Or do you set their rule over the earth? Do you lift up your voice to the clouds, so that floods of water cover you? Do you send out lightnings, and they go and say to you, ‘Here we are!’? Who has put wisdom in the inward parts? Or who has given understanding to the heart? Who has wisdom to count the clouds, or to tip over the bottles of the heavens, when the dust hardens in clumps, and the clods cling together? Do you hunt the prey for the lion, or satisfy the appetite of the young lions, when they crouch in dens, sit in the cover of their hiding place? Who provides food for the raven, when its young ones cry to Ěl, and wander about without food?

What a great video :) As a Canadian who has seen many snowy winters, lived and worked in the far north, visited AK and the Yukon and other arctic lands  (and yet, like most North Americans, never been north of the Arctic Circle), I really enjoyed this and could relate to a lot of the cold weather scenes,  the logistics of operating in cold and remote locations, etc.  While Destin’s science background and knowledge always amaze, two minor things jumped out:  the Beaufort is pronounced Bow-fort, not Biew-Fort;  and that atmospheric phenomenon you noticed are called Sun Dogs.  They are indeed caused by ice crystals in the air and create a pattern of light at specific angles (22 degrees) relative to the sun and at the same vertical angle, due to the refractive index of ice.  The refracted light then reflects off other ice crystals toward the viewer, similar to how rainbows work, and in certain conditions can form a halo all the way around the sun or moon.  Similar effects at different refractive indexes in clouds and atmospheric ice conditions create things called light pillars, sun pillars, moon halos. The science behind this is quite interesting and creates beautiful and spectacular images.  Check out the Astronomy Picture of the Day (apod) website which contains a huge archive of scientifically curated and described images, mostly space images but lots of atmospheric phenomena too.  Maybe this could be a topic for a future Smarter video? :). Love your channel and I’m already  looking forward to the subsequent videos on the sub! Keep up the great work!

Welp, I was stationed at SubBase New London in Groton Connecticut. That was 1979. I was often down on lower base and ate chow on the USS Richard B Russell SSN687. My friend was a fire control tech attached and had me visit onboard quite a bit. I also was able to bring my Dad on a "buddy cruise". We were underway from Groton up to Newport RI or so doodling around for about 5 hours. Alot of the boat was restricted, but we looked through the periscope, experienced a couple of dives and the fellas fired water slugs, Dad got to hear all the official Navy type goings-on. I was probably one of the only female enlisted to be able to do so. I kind of took it for granted at the time...I'm sure old DickieB had nothing on the shiny icebreaker featured above..but it was an afternoon that my Dad enjoyed.

I helped build the camp in 2007 for ice-x.  The views are absolutely stunning looking out from the camp.  The only bummer was that we didn't have any super active aurora, but at night you could see these silver ribbons crossing the night sky.  And the stars were freaking amazing.  I remember my first day there, mostly because the first thing I had to do was build my shelter, get the heat going for it, and build up my bed. They changed up what most of the buildings are from when I was there, we built a bunch of wood buildings and a few of the bread loaf buildings.  This year looks like all bread loaf buildings. 2007 we had a few universities there, but we also had some of the cast for Stargate SG1 there to film scenes for an episode.  I was only up on the ice there for 9 days, but it's something I'll never forget and wish I could do all over again.

Hey Destin, as a person who goes ice-fishing, I have seen a lot of those ice behaviors in person but never knew the names for them. I will say on big lakes like Lake Erie it dangerous to go out unless there is a lot of ice because it moves so much. I was taught never to go out on less than 5 inches but I believe 3 can hold a person(though then any little change and you have trouble). I was also taught to never go near the finger rafting spots, I have only even seen them on Lake Erie( maybe smaller lake don't move the ice enough to see them), but I was always taught that when the ice goes over itself like that you no longer know where the ice is strong. So potentially you could be walking along on double the normal ice thickness and then there will be a void where the ice is only an inch thick and you wouldn't be able to tell. Also they tend to get stuck together and not want to separate so when the ice moves again they can cause big tear to happen and you could have open water between you and shore. Anyways I am no expert was taught this by my fisherman father and grandfather, cool video hope some one finds this interesting.

7:40 That looks to be a 22° halo with sundogs. Both are caused by the flat, hexagonal ice crystals floating in the air.
This more often occurs in high altitude clouds (eg Cirrostratus) but in your case, you are experiencing "diamond dust" which is a ground-level could. Note the occasional small, brief but bright flashes when a crystal closer to the camera turns face-on.
The dogs to either side are where the 22° halo intersects with the parhelic arc (in this case would be close to a horizontal line) which is due to many of the crystals being approximately horizontally aligned (most stable orientation wrt air resistance) as they fall.

The USS Toledo!  I almost went underway on the boat by accident.  The boat was sharing a pier with another that I was scheduled to work on (had to fix one of their subsystems).  I asked the good folks of the Toledo if their corresponding system was having any issues, and turned out it was, so I offered to take a look.  As I was working on it, things started to get very busy, so I asked what was going on.  They informed me that the boat was leaving for deployment in about 10 minutes, and they all thought I was planning on joining them.  I hauled myself off that boat right quick, otherwise I'd have been swimming back.

UAF is, literally, five minutes from where I live, in the University Heights area. Everything in the Fairbanks section, especially the University, was like déjà vu. And yes, -30 Fahrenheit is a common occurrence here, with -40 reached every winter (Fahrenheit and Celsius are the same at -40, it is the only point at which they meet).
Destin saw an "ice-bow," fairly common depending on the concentration of ice crystals in the air. It is especially prominent during periods of ice fog. Ice fog is as weird as it sounds, and both very pretty when the light hits it and slightly hazardous (breathing, driving, etc.).

If you're not familiar with this, you should really look into the efforts the military put into controlling PR following Vietnam. Vietnam was a conflict in which news media played a big part in exposing what was wrong with policy. Many millions of people died in Vietnam, and the only reason the American people woke to that was media access that was open and uncontrolled by the military. But that's not how it's worked since then. The Persian Gulf War was one of the first wars that really showed full control of the media, and it led to a lot less criticism of their policies.

I spent 2 years in Ft. Greely, Alaska as a contractor. Yes, that flight from Huntsville to Fairbanks is a long one; I did it twice about every 2 months (down and back), and it's your whole day -- usually about 13 hours from first takeoff to final landing.
Ironically, I arrived in late January 2009 while it was just below freezing at 29°F. As I waited outside the Fairbanks airport for my ride, I had to strip down to my short sleeves. With no moisture in the air and no wind, even a simple leather jacket was too warm. On the other side of that, the warm snap meant winds at Ft. Greely were up to 50 mph gusts. The wind whipping between buildings could literally suck the breath out of you. You learn to appreciate the -30°F temps, as when it's cold, the wind is minimal. You can dress in layers for the cold, but a 25+ mph wind will cut right through your clothing. I'll take -30°F and no wind over 0°F and windy any day.

I see a lot of frustration with the nature of these weapons which are nuclear submarines. You must remember we live in a world where the vast number of communities in this world no matter how rich and now matter how lively and vibrant can be snuffed out due to political convenience without respect for human life. And these are tragedies that must be avoided at all cost. This is my view point both as someone who has served in the US military and as a US citizen, no matter the competition or enemy I do not wish to see them annihilated by nuclear force. However this reality is what also keeps military expansion from powerful nations in check. If China invaded India in an egregious manner that deeply threatened their national security Beijing would be removed from the face of the earth by nuclear force and vis a vis for Delhi. I deeply hope this never occurs. So regardless of a deep aversion there is a profound necessity to maintain this condition where all human life on the planet can be wiped out in 2 hours. Because the reality becomes apparent human life is worthless as we remain divided and secure when cooperation can be achieved as an ultimatum. It is a death pact of sorts where anyone that wants global domination at the tremendous expense of human life can be denied. The what-about-isms of various nuclear powers committing abuses such as Russia in the Ukraine, the US in Iraq, and China among almost all of it's neighboring countries are meaningless as this abuse of power is ubiquitous and must be deterred by free and powerful democracies which two of those nations lack and hence are unaccountable by their own people. I believe voters denying the warmonger Hillary Clinton is evident that the US people are overtly leaning towards military de-escalation and changing policy reflects that barring instigation (example: by political radicals such as groups within the Iranian government who would not care if they annihilated themselves out of spite). The only true defeat of nuclear weapons is not decrying their existence but removing the conditions we set for ourselves that necessitate them. If there were no need for any of us to commit to militaristic expansion there would be no need for nuclear weapons except for extra-planetary threats.

edit: This did not age well. A few days after this post there was a confrontation between India and China that resulted in the deaths of +40 CCP soldiers and 20 Indian soldiers. Hey, Destin, I hope in an upcoming video you talk a bit more about arctic militarization. It is a very controversial subject from a few angles: should we be putting any military stuffs in the Arctic, or should it be reserved for purely scientific and energy extraction purposes? How should we go about militarizing this niche environment? While the US, Russia, and our allies have poured billions of dollars into ships that can operate in the arctic, they have been wildly unsuccessful overall (because of the need to cut ice, because ice moves, etc). I was a helmsman on the USS Trepang, SSN 674 when we took part in ICEX 1985. There were 3 ice camps taking part and they were all three much further north than this ice camp. One of them only 300 miles from the pole. We had scientists on board with a supercomputer (probably slower than my phone today) that studied how sound traveled under the ice. Possibly research that led in part to these experiments today. Once our duties with ICEX ended, we headed to the North Pole and surfaced through 6 feet of ice. We surfaced thru the ice 10 times during the trip. I was at the helm for 4 surfaces and 6 dives. I was at the stern planes when we dove at the Pole. We were frozen in place and had to bring in over 40,000lbs of seawater before we broke through. We then sank straight down like a 40,000lb rock. We were at 400' before we even started to slow down and didn't completely catch it until 800'. At the stern planes, I was responsible for large elevation changes, so it was a bit exciting for a minute there.

Thanks for the video. I look forward to your video from inside the boat. Hopefully they don't delete too much of it. I have more, unique observances from the Pole, with photos, if you're interested.

Rear Adm. Dollaga is a native of Vallejo, California, and a 1990 graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy with a Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering.  He holds a Master in Engineering Management from George Washington University in Washington, District of Columbia.

His sea tours include division officer assignments aboard USS Los Angeles (SSN 688); engineer officer aboard USS Rhode Island (SSBN 740)(B); and executive officer aboard USS Cheyenne (SSN 773).  He commanded USS Charlotte (SSN 766) in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii and also served as commodore of Submarine Development Squadron 12, Groton, Connecticut.

His staff assignments include admissions officer at the U.S. Naval Academy; technical assistant to the Director of Naval Nuclear Propulsion; nuclear officer program manager and the submarine officer community manager on the staff of the Deputy Chief of Naval Operations (Manpower, Personnel, Training, and Education); Commander, Submarine Force, U.S. Pacific Fleet prospective commanding officer instructor (Submarine Command Course); chief, program and budget branch on the Joint Staff (J8) Directorate (Program and Budget Analysis Division); and director, Congressional Liaison Appropriations Matters Office (FMBE) on the staff of the Assistant Secretary of the Navy (FM&C).

He has completed three overseas deployments in Indo-Pacific Command and five strategic deterrent patrols in the Atlantic.

Dollaga assumed his current duties as commander, Undersea Warfighting Development Center in May 2018.

The units he served with collectively earned four unit awards, five Battle “E”s, and U.S. Pacific Fleet’s Arleigh Burke Fleet Trophy.

I think we should acknowledge that, although no money has exchanged hands, both Destin Sandlin and the U.S. Navy have benefitted from this video. To be sure, we would expect parties to benefit from any voluntary transaction between them. However, Mr. Sandlin has at two points during the video, once near the beginning and once near the end, emphasized the moneyless and uncensorsed aspects of his ICEX experience. This is partly (and almost certainly unintentionally) misleading, as something of value has been exchanged: access to rare and appealing information. The U.S. Navy has granted Mr. Sandlin, a professional YouTuber, a monetizable commodity in exchange for its own ends, which, I suspect, are positive domestic publicity and impactful soft diplomacy.

Furthermore, although Mr. Sandlin writes that
"The US Navy put no restrictions on me about what I should say or how I should present what I learned on this trip.
Other than making sure my footage was cleared for Operational Security, I am free to say whatever I want about this experience."
Sandlin's career as a missile-flight test engineer and his many previous YouTube videos about military matters were, I believe, part of the reason the Navy invited Mr. Sandlin to view its Arctic base and operations. Sandlin's expressed opinions about the United States Armed Forces have been primarily favorable, and so, athough it was something of a calculated risk, Navy decision-makers likely concluded that no overt content restrictions (aside from OpSec, which is a form of censorship) were necessary. In effect, censorship occurred (benign and innocuous though it may have been), not after Mr. Sandlin's filming via restrictions on footage content, but during the selection of Mr. Sandlin himself.

Thank you for sharing this unique opportunity through this very interesting video! I do totally understand and share your excitement for all the science and technology. However, I´m concerned about the way you are talking about the military.
Especially in times like these, where millions loose there jobs, tens of thousands die and good education isn´t available for many, it becomes obvious, that the real danger for the people isn´t originating from some foreign powers and countries. Huge investments in the social systems, public health care, public education and combating the climate catastrophe are urgent to do something about the problems and dangers people are facing every day and that are only becoming more problematic in the future. Instead, money is wastefully being poured into the military.
To make it worse, arming the military doesn´t actually help keeping peace, it achieves the contrary. It´s the old intimidation technique that was used during the cold war. Party A stocks up their military to intimidate party B. That forces party B to upgrade their military as well to be equally or even more powerful than party A. Party A then feels pressured to increase their military again and the play continues. It´s like a spiral, just like we saw during the cold war. But the more powerful each party grows, the more tense the situation gets. If a conflict actually erupts, the consequences of a shooting war become more and more devastating for all of humanity. So instead of trying to intimidate each other, we should really try to disarm and shrink all military to a minimum size that might still be necessary to protect us from potential terrorist attacks etc. We should but our focus in cooperating with other countries and try to get a good relationship so that we stop feeling like we have to intimidate each other! War usually creates more problems than it “solves”, if it does actually solve any.
Also, especially being out on the arctic sea ice, which is declining every year due to the effects of the climate crisis, praising one of the single largest CO2 emitters, the US military, seems pretty strange. If the US military was a country, it would be within the top 60 of the most CO2 emitting ones. So, investing in the military actually threatens the future of the very people it is sworn to protect.
I cannot understand how someone like you, dedicated to science and understanding the world using observations and facts, is praising an organization without questioning it or taking different view points into consideration. But I do think I understand where you are coming from. Of course, being part of a nation with the strongest military in the world that defends you from all those enemies must feel great and does make for a nice story. But that is not the reality. Reality is complex. With other scientific topics you are able to communicate that complexity really well. So Why not here? I do not expect you to agree with my opinion, but you could really build criticism into your coverage and allow for different points of view. After all, how do you plan to become “smarter” without questioning?
Your sincerely,
Julius

Thank you Dustin for such entertaining and informative videos. I anxiously await the next videos on this once in a lifetime experience.  I have an uncle who began his submarine service on the USS Trutta (SS-421), and later on the USS George Washington (CVN-73). My submarine story centers around a visit with my uncle when he was stationed in Key West when I was 10 years old. I was able to visit the Trutta and was allowed the opportunity to use its periscope to view the surrounding area. The highlight of that experience was to view the heavily guarded USS Nautilus (SSN-571), the first nuclear powered submarine. Thankfully nothing happened when I requested to fire a torpedo at the Nautilus. A boy's imagination. Seeing the Nautilus was a foreshadowing of my future career.  I too am an Alabama graduate, '72 BS Aerospace/BS Mechanical and then spent almost 40 years in design and support of nuclear power plants in the Southeast. I admire your presentation of such great content and wish you continued success.

Hey Destin, that halo around the sun is called a Sun Dog. It is caused due to the refraction of light through ice crystals. They usually are located 22 degrees left or right of the sun. I'm a former student at the University of North Dakota and during our winters we have the amazing privilege to see them during our winters. If your interested in doing a video on it, there are some really amazing meteorology professes at UND that could help. I've also taken a lot of cool pictures of them while up here if you would like me to send them to you. I love all your videos, and you keep me searching for something new to learn and experience.

What I think is really cool, is that you can see how the cold is effecting everyone's brain.  You can see how smart all of these people are, getting little glimpses of how articulate and specific their field of study is, but over that the light fog they have.  It takes them longer to process a question of what they do, or they don't respond to first bumps.  They take longer to think about their answers.  All because their brain is handling the cold, their bodies under stress. I know it's heated, but having been exposed to that level of cold myself, I totally get the slow down.  I'm sure that's something else the military loves to see!  How long can fighters operate effectively in arctic conditions, how their reaction times are affected, and how to maximize personnel effectiveness in extreme environments.

Hey Destin,
I'm from Germany, maybe I have another view on a military topic, but I really don't like how you talk about "defending the constitution".
Don't understand me wrong. The American culture is heavily influenced by the military, weapons lobby and so on, but the feeling that you gave me and I think others too, just two minutes into the video was:
There is a real threat out there that could attack the US and bring the whole world back to much worse times. Like a new cold war. I honour people, all over the world dedicate their lives to protect others/the country. This needs courage and bravery, but I think humans need to change to a society that is not solving their problems with threatening others with bigger military, violence or other ways of brutality.
I mean you just said it, this video was filmed before the death of George Floyd, but especially the US culture is a very violent one. You as an influencer and YouTuber with 8,3 million subscribers need to think about the content you are creating. Sure you are doing a ton of work for every video.
The videos I most like from you are those where I learn fascinating new stuff, physics or other things, but this is the second time I'm really questioning your choice of content. Sure it is cool how you board a nuclear submarine in the arctic, and sure there are a lot of interesting high skilled humans on board, but defending the constitution against what, who?
Where is the enemy? Russia? Chinese? Europa?
Humans living in other countries with other Socalstructures have the same wishes then everyone else. Shelter, food and a good life for his/her beloved ones.
I guarantee you, weapons and violence will never be the solution to a peaceful world. Because hate causes hate on both sides of the coin.
